clinical_study.brief_title: Level of Accelerometer-assessed Preoperative Physical Activity and Short Term Outcome After Elective Cardiac Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Level of Accelerometer-assessed Preoperative Physical Activity and Short Term Outcome After Elective Cardiac Surgery. A Monocentric Prospective Observational Cohort Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

clinical_study.source: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

brief_summary.textblock: Short term morbidity after elective cardiac surgery remains significant. Standard predictive models, considering simple patient demographics and clinical parameters, show limited efficiency in individual operative risk assessment. There is growing evidence about daily physical activity as a relevant indicator of preoperative "frailty". Although cardiopulmonary exercise testing remains a gold standard, we are looking for more simple tools in order to identify patients with poor physical condition. Accelerometry may be an objective and reproductible method to measure physical activity at patient's home.

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of this study is to compare accelerometer-assessed preoperative physical activity between two groups of patients with different postoperative length of stay following elective cardiac surgery. In the future, accelerometry could be used to identify patients that may benefit from prehabilitation programs including exercise therapy before elective cardiac surgery.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean daily preoperative walking activity (average of steps/day over a period of 7 days)

secondary_outcome.measure: Total energy expenditure evaluated over a 7 days (steps/day)
Low activity time in hours per week (hours/week)
Moderate activity time in hours per week (hours/week)
Intense activity time in hours per week (hours/week)
Time of very intense activity in hours per week (hours/week)
Sleep time in hours per week (hours/week)
Analysis of questionary Duke Activity Status Index (DASI) over a period of 7 days
secondary_outcome.description: Questionary Duke Activity Status Index (DASI) estimates the maximum volume of oxygen used in one minute (VO2 Max) as well as its effort capacity in metabolic equivalent. It contains 11 items. The higher the score indicates better functional capacity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Analysis of questionary Short Nutritional Assessment Questionnaire (SNAQ) over a period of 7 days
secondary_outcome.description: Questionary Short Nutritional Assessment Questionnaire (SNAQ) evaluates nutritional status. The higher the score indicates an important nutritional support.

secondary_outcome.measure: Relationship between preoperative physical activity and duration of stay in intensive care
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between preoperative physical activity and duration of stay in intensive care.

secondary_outcome.measure: Preoperative clinical outcome and duration of stay in intensive care
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between preoperative clinical outcome and duration of stay in intensive care.

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative clinical outcome and duration of stay in intensive care
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between postoperative clinical outcome and duration of stay in intensive care.

arm_group.description: Patients with a postoperative intensive care unity length of stay ≥ 5 days after elective cardiac surgery. They will have an accelerometer.
Patients with a postoperative intensive care unity length of stay < 5 days after elective cardiac surgery. They will have an accelerometer.

intervention.description: Patient will wear the accelerometer for 7 consecutive days to measure the level of physical activity.

study_pop.textblock: Adult subject (≥ 60 years) awaiting elective cardiac surgery will be included.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult subject (≥ 60 years) awaiting elective cardiac surgery
- Patients affiliated or entitled to a social security scheme
- Patients who have received information about the study and have given their oral consent to participate
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant woman,
- Major limitations in physical activity for orthopedic or musculoskeletal reasons
- Patients under judicial protection (curator or guardianship)
